solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 88 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{88}{\pi} = 28 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 88 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 88 + 28\)
= 36.8 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(88 cm^2\). You then cut a straight slice from the cake (as shown below) such that the volume of the slice is exactly \(\frac {1}{10}\) of the volume of the cake. What surface area of your slice has no icing?

hint.text: Think about your slice as a separate object. What faces do not have icing?

content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 1664 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(1664 m^2\)
Therefore, \(1664 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{1664}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{16}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 4 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Area of Garden = Area of Plot - Area of the House
\(= ab - cd\)
\(= (3939 - 49(16)) m^2\)
\(=3155 m^2\)

content.text: Kshitij is looking to landscape his garden. He made a diagram of his house (grey colour) but forgot to mention the exact dimensions of the garden area. You are the engineer in charge of the project. Can you use the information given below to calculate the area of the garden? a = 101 m, b = 39 m, c = 49 m, d = 16 m

hint.text: Try subtracting areas to find the right answer

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)
\(= \frac 12 \times 21 \times (24 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{882}{10.5} - 24\)
\(= 60 m\)

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

\(= 2 (7 \times 3 + 3 \times 7 + 7 \times 7) = 182 cm^2\)
Therefore, area of tin required for 7 boxes \(= 182 \times 7\)
\(= 1274 cm^2\)

content.text: You need to create a tin box of dimensions \(7 cm \times 3 cm \times 7 cm.\) What is the area of a sheet of tin required to make 7 such tins?

hint.text: Start by calculating the surface area of the box

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 121 \times 37 + \frac 12 \times 52\times(121 + 91)\)
\(= 9989 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 4 km/hr = 4000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 9989 \times 4000 = 39956000 m^3/hr\)
= 39956 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 39956\)
= 6712608 megalitres

Therefore, the volume will quadruple

V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\(V_ {new} = \pi (\frac r2)^2h = \frac V4\)
Therefore, the volume will quarter

content.text: If the radius is halved:
A cylinder has a radius r, a height h and a volume V

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 1848\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{1848}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{1848}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {1848\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 14 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 7 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 4312 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 1848 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 6688 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {11}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {11}{2} - 6)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {11}2)^2-\pi (\frac {11}2 - m)^2}\)
= 70.93 cm

Area of each face =\(3.3^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 326.7 - 108.9 = 217.8 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 10 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(217.8 \times 10\)
= Rs. 2178

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 7165.71 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (11)^2 \times 40 - \pi (11-x)^2 \times 40\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{40\pi}=11^2 - (11-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (11-x)^2 = 121 - \frac{V}{40\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 11 - 8\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

content.text: The inner diameter of a metallic tube is 17 cm. The thickness of the rim is 4 cm and the length is 30 cm. If the density of the metal is \(\frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\), what is the mass of the pipe?

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{29}2 \times 7 + 2 \pi \times \frac{6}2 \times 7 + 2\pi({\frac{29}2}^2 - {\frac{6}2}^2)\)
= 2035\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 2035 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 407

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 24 cm and breadth 10 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 24 cm long. What is the volume of the air inside the cylinder so formed?

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 13^2 \times 45 = 23901.43 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 23901.43 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 30 \times 17 \times h = 23901.43 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {23901.43}{30 \times 17} = 46.87\)
The new cuboid is 46.87 cm tall

\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 10 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 10000\)
